verses.text: You shall make the altar of acacia wood, five cubits long and five cubits wide. The altar shall be square, and its height shall be three cubits.
verses.comment: The altar’s size and material reflect its importance and durability for continual sacrifice, foreshadowing future altars used in worship. The square design underscores symmetry and completeness, themes frequently seen in biblical symbols (see Rev. 21:16).

verses.text: You shall make horns on its four corners; its horns shall be of one piece with it. And you shall overlay it with bronze.
verses.comment: The altar’s horns signify power, protection, and forgiveness; later, fugitives sought refuge there (see 1 Kgs. 1:50). Bronze symbolizes strength and judgment, fitting for the place of offering. This altar foreshadows the cross, where ultimate forgiveness is found.

verses.text: You shall make its pots for removing ashes, its shovels, its basins, its forks, and its firepans. All its utensils you shall make of bronze.
verses.comment: The detail for each tool shows care for all aspects of worship. Each function plays a part in ordered worship, hinting at the structure and tradition in faith practice. Bronze’s continued use reaffirms the importance and dignity attached to offering sacrifices.

verses.text: You shall make for it a grating, a network of bronze, and on the net you shall make four bronze rings at its four corners.
verses.comment: The grating allowed ashes to fall, symbolizing purification. The four rings on the corners reflect the completeness and universality of God’s call (see Rev. 7:1—four corners of the earth). Unity and permanence meant to endure through generations.

verses.text: You shall put it beneath, under the ledge of the altar, so that the net may reach halfway up the altar.
verses.comment: Placing the net halfway up shows thoughtful instructions from God, ensuring order. Practical details like these emphasize the importance of worship’s visible and invisible aspects—calling believers to interior devotion as well as outward practice.

verses.text: You shall make poles for the altar, poles of acacia wood, and overlay them with bronze.
verses.comment: Poles signify readiness to move; the altar is portable so God’s presence moves with His people. This foreshadows the Church journeying in the world, carrying sacred tradition wherever believers go.

verses.text: You shall put the poles through the rings on the sides of the altar, to carry it.
verses.comment: Only appointed servants move the altar, upholding sacred order and authority. Order is key in the Christian community, linking OT priesthood to the NT call for leaders overseen by apostolic succession.

verses.text: You shall make it hollow, with boards. As they were shown to you on the mountain, so shall they make it.
verses.comment: ‘As shown on the mountain’ emphasizes God’s revelation and adherence to divine instruction. Following the heavenly pattern is crucial—mirroring the unwavering faithfulness Christ demonstrated (see Heb. 8:5).

verses.text: You shall make the courtyard of the tabernacle. On the south side, there shall be hangings for the court of fine linen, one hundred cubits long for one side.
verses.comment: The courtyard’s linen hangings represent purity and separation for holy service. The enclosure hints at sanctified places and gatherings set apart to worship God, prefiguring ongoing practices in Christian worship.

verses.text: And its twenty pillars with their twenty bronze bases, the hooks of the pillars and their bands shall be of silver.
verses.comment: Silver, often a symbol of redemption (see Num. 18:16), is used here in the bands and hooks, showing sacred function and securing the hangings—emphasizing the importance of beauty, order, and costly devotion in worship.

verses.text: Likewise, on the north side, hangings one hundred cubits long, twenty pillars and their twenty bronze bases; the hooks of the pillars and their bands shall be of silver.
verses.comment: Repetition conveys thoroughness and the seriousness of God’s instructions. The uniform design increases accessibility and highlights unity among God’s people around sacred space.

verses.text: And for the west side, there shall be hangings fifty cubits long, with ten pillars and their ten bases.
verses.comment: Different measurements on each side mirror the tabernacle’s orientation, which was always east-facing. Eastward direction remains symbolic throughout Scripture as a sign of readiness, anticipation, and resurrection (see Matt. 24:27).

verses.text: The width of the court on the east side shall be fifty cubits.
verses.comment: The east side offered entrance. This orientation, repeated in temple construction, connects to Christ who is called the ‘Dayspring from on high’ (Luke 1:78), symbolizing light and new beginnings.

verses.text: The hangings for one side of the gate shall be fifteen cubits, with three pillars and three bases.
verses.comment: Specific gate measurements ensure ordered access. The gate connects outer gathering with sacred inner worship, revealing the careful progression from separation to communion, as through sacraments.

verses.text: For the other side of the gate, hangings fifteen cubits, with three pillars and three bases.
verses.comment: Mirrored designs teach balance and order in worship. The repetition of pillars at the entrance prefigures the appointed guardian-role of leaders protecting sacred things.

verses.text: For the gate of the court there shall be a screen twenty cubits long, of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely woven linen, the work of an embroiderer; with four pillars and four bases.
verses.comment: The colors blue, purple, and scarlet symbolize divinity, royalty, and sacrifice (see Heb. 9:19). Embroidered linen indicates dedication of skilled service, a pointer to beauty in worship and the value of liturgical art.

verses.text: All the pillars around the court shall have silver bands; their hooks shall be of silver, and their bases of bronze.
verses.comment: The combination of silver and bronze unites themes of redemption and judgment, foreshadowing the New Covenant where mercy and justice meet in Christ (see Ps. 85:10).

verses.text: The length of the court shall be one hundred cubits, the width fifty cubits, and the height five cubits, with fine linen hangings and bronze bases.
verses.comment: These set boundaries create defined worship space—teaching order, separation, and reverence. The enclosure typifies the heavenly worship described in Revelation (Rev. 4:8-11), where the saints adore from within the presence.

verses.text: All the utensils of the tabernacle for every use, and all its stakes and all the stakes of the court, shall be of bronze.
verses.comment: Bronze denotes strength and endurance, fitting for the tools of persistent, ongoing worship. Every implement is sacred—reflecting the importance given to the smallest acts in Christian service (see 1 Cor. 10:31).

verses.text: You shall command the Israelites to bring pure beaten olive oil for the light, to keep the lamp burning regularly.
verses.comment: Olive oil for the light symbolizes the Spirit’s presence and illumination. The perpetual flame points to continual prayer and worship, a theme later fulfilled in Christian liturgy and the command to pray without ceasing (see 1 Thess. 5:17).

verses.text: In the Tent of Meeting, outside the veil that is before the testimony, Aaron and his sons shall tend it from evening until morning before the LORD. This shall be a lasting ordinance for the Israelites throughout their generations.
verses.comment: Priestly service is perpetual, showing succession and continuity. The unending watch over the lamp presages the ongoing ministry passed down through appointed leaders, ensuring the light of faith never ceases in the community (see Matt. 5:14-16).
